[[File:20,000 martyrs of Nicomedia (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|300px|thumb|Miniature from the ''[[Menologion of Basil II]]'' honoring the Martyrs of Nicomedia]] The '''20,000 Martyrs of Nicomedia''' refers to victims of [[persecution of Christians]] in [[Nicomedia]] by the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] Emperors [[Diocletian]] and [[Maximian]] in the early [[4th century]] AD.
According to various [[martyrology|martyrologies]] and [[menologion]], the persecution included the burning of a church that held numerous Christians on [[Christmas Day]]. The [[Roman Martyrology]] reports four groups of martyrs from that time.
The number 20,000 may be apocryphal.<ref name="Walsh2007"/> However, the martyrs of Nicomedia continue to be honored with feast days:<ref name="Walsh2007">{{cite book|author=Michael J. Walsh|title=A New Dictionary of Saints: East and West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8mUJ58SMMhEC&pg=PA401|accessdate=23 August 2012|date=30 July 2007|publisher=Liturgical Press|isbn=978-0-8146-3186-7|page=401}}</ref> they are commemorated on 28 December in the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], and by the [[Byzantine Catholic]] and [[Latin Rite]] Catholic Churches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orthodox.net/menaion-december/28-20000-holy-martyrs-of-nicomedia.html|title=The 20,000 Holy Martyrs of Nicomedia|work=St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Church|accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref>
